results.title: Orbital shapes and paths
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
How is a satellite placed in a desired orbit? The program explores this problem by illustrating how a satellite’s shape, path and period may be modified. Practical application of this procedure - the establishing of weather and communications satellites - is demonstrated as students are given a satellite’s eye view of the various paths over the earth’s surface.

results.title: Principles of orbit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
How do the laws of inertia and universal gravitation govern the flight of an orbiting satellite? This program investigates the question by demonstrating the behaviour of a satellite, both in circular and elliptical orbit.
results.description:

results.title: Rendezvous
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This program examines the application of necessary physical laws to bring two orbiting space craft to a meeting in space. “Rendezvous” illustrates accomplishing a complete rendezvous manoeuvre when two spacecraft are in different orbits and on different planes.
results.description:

results.title: The Milky way
results.creator_credit: ACI Films and United World Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This film presents a scientist’s conception of how stars were formed. It includes a brief explanation of the Milky Way and shows the telescopes used to study stars, light and radio waves. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Energy in orbit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This program uses animated dramatisation to examine the characteristics of potential and kinetic energy, and the ways in which these forces affect a satellite’s orbit.

results.title: Over the hill to the moon
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
How does a spacecraft overcome the conflicting gravity pulls when travelling from earth to the moon? This program addresses this problem and also dramatises an entire lunar flight through the use of animation and exciting live footage.

results.title: Flight to the planets
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
Examines both the principles that govern flight to the planets and the gravitational pull of each of the nine planets of our solar system.

results.title: Working: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
A look at the Soviet economy in the 1970’s. Examines some of the Industrial developments, investigates output, productivity, the relationships between management and the trade unions, and management and individual workers. Also examines working conditions and salaries in a coal mine, a refrigerator factory, a timber processing complex, and dock workers in Odessa

results.title: People of influence
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield, John Abbott and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
The troika, which governs the lives of all working Russians is illustrated. The film shows the relationship between the Director, the Trade Union chairman and the Party secretary of an enterprise. The Director of the enterprise is shown at a coal mine, supervising his men; the Party Secretary’s influence aids the workers in a gravel washing enterprise; a Trade Union Chairman is seen at work at a refrigerator factory and shows her responsibilities. Cameraman, Dean Semler; editors, Tom Foley, Wayne Le Clos.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield, John Abbott and Film Australia
